ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin!
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin is incredibly bright and I valued that he offered an interesting and informative counter/alternate take that supported my overall understanding. Craig and Martin offered good balance, and for me at least, it was helpful to take in the material via multiple presentations. Martin was very accessible and generous with his time for review sessions, which I also found invaluable.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Knows the material inside-out, accesible, great at explaining it!

Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin is a very intelligent and lucid thinker, and he greatly contributed to the learning of the class. He was also made himself readily available for questions, concerns, and review. I don't have any significant weaknesses to point out.

Instructor: Martin Bouda  He's the man! Greatly enjoyed/benefited from review sessions with him and his in-class comments. Sometimes in the review sessions however there would be tangents in his explanations that, though interesting, were not the topics which needed to be addressed.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Deep knowledge in the field, the review session was really helpful

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 3: the load was about the same, but the readings took me (with no background in plant physiology) longer than usual

Question 12: Craig would give extremely detailed and well-thought out responses to comments during class, and often encouraged comments and discussion. Question 14: This course presented very unique material that is otherwise difficult to learn. I did not recognize the value of plant hydraulics until after taking this course

This course was very valuable and I learned a lot. I would have liked to have a little bit more of an introduction to the material before charging into the discussion - maybe incorporate more of an organized lecture component during part of the class time.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: One of the best aspects was the small class size, combined with Craig's openness to adapt the course. The chalk-talks were really helpful to get everyone up to speed (quite a feat considering the diversity of backgrounds represented in the room).
Very important information- great to have both an academic and applied perspective.
Interesting course material presented in an understandable way
Interesting topics and lecture materials, cool gadgetry, humor.

To get to know the broad pictures of the plant hydraulics through various readings and course materials Craig and Martin is really helpful, they spent so many hours to make sure if the student fully understand the class materials
The instructor is well-organized, explains concepts clearly and makes expectations clear. Time spent in lab was a great learning opportunity.
I liked the organic nature of the class and the fact the Craig was willing to change the trajectory of the course based on student interest.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There were some minor kinks in the system, to be expected in a first class. 3 hour Monday lectures felt really long at first-- but I came to appreciate them over the long run, and would not change them in retrospect. But, sticking closely to a set break time half-way through would be helpful. Getting into the lab to check as soon as possible would have been great, too (though not humanly possible this fall given Greeley's renovations).
It needs a better flow. Many classes the instructor seemed to run out of material and not quite know what to do with us.
Organization of the course still needs work, including student-led class discussions. There was general uncertainty as to the expectations for these, as well as the class paper/project.
Class periods need to be better structured. It often felt like we were just eating up time by the end of the period. Perhaps 3 hour sessions are not the right length.
It would be helpful if the instructor will provide a lecture on - brief lectures on the plan physiology - technical terms ( if difficult, review session by TA would be helpful!)
More hands on learning would be great - more time in the lab.
I don't feel like I got a solid grounding in the material from class discussions, though I did learn a lot of interesting pieces of information.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There wasn't much of a lab component. The discssions during the second half of the semester were great.

The discussions were mostly good towards the second half of the semester when we had them, but sometimes felt a bit aimless. Time spent beforehand going over te nuts and bolts of the reading materials would be beneficial.
if would be helpful if we had a longer lab session, but it was really helpful!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: A great alternative to a more traditional plant phys class.
one of the selective requirements

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: As an alternative presentation of plant physiology and anatomy to Professor Berlyn's approach and out of interest for plants' hydraulic features as a building block for addressing pressing concerns with climate change and population pressures
I needed a better understanding of how plants function, especially in the light of a changing climate and greater aridity.
I am very interested in plants and how they interact with the environment.
I love plants and wanted to better understand this crucial process within them.
I was interested in strengthen the scientific knowledge

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I learned far more than I anticipated and really enjoyed this class.
Yes- great class overall! Could be expanded a bit and more well planned, but considering that this was its first time, it was awesome.
I learned much more from this course than I expected, so I would argue they exceeded my expectations.
And then some.
yes, I feel like I learned more than I though,
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working as a group to organize a discussion was great and helped to get students more involved.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read carefully at the start, and stick with obtaining the basic proficiencies, because the later applications (plant drought response and tolerance, angiosperm and gymnosperm development/diversion, understanding ranges/morphological characteristics/plasticity of plants) are widespread, important, and being done whether we like and understand them or not!
Take it!
The class is loosely structured, and be prepared to talk and discuss. You won't just be lectured at for the entire time period, you should expect to be somewhat involved.
Do your readings!
The course focuses on very specific content material. If you are interested in plant hydraulics, it is a good intro to the field.
